image.altText: Deputy Premier of Victoria Jacinta Allan speaks to media during a press conference.

items.synopsis: Among those sanctioned were 12 members of South Australia's Australia Day council.

title.children: Russia sanctions 48 Australians in latest sweep punishing 'Russophobic' groups

image.altText: An armoured vehicle is pictured on a dark street as people are looking at it.

items.synopsis: The founder of Russia's Wagner mercenary force, Yevgeny Prigozhin, said on Saturday that his men had crossed border from Ukraine into Russia and were ready to go "all the way" against the Russian military.

title.children: Russian mercenary boss says his men crossed into Russia: We're ready to go 'all the way'

image.altText: A photo of a white submersible under water.

items.synopsis: Days of frantic waiting has ended in tragedy for the families of the Titan sub passengers. But the search for answers is just beginning, and the question now is whether lessons will be learned from the underwater implosion.

title.children: The Titan sub mystery unfolded in unimaginable horror. For those on board, it was over in a moment

image.altText: Jim gestures as he speaks at a podium.

items.synopsis: As our federal politicians prepare for their five-week winter break, two significant developments which point to much of what will shape the country — and political debate — in coming months haven't really been quite noticed, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: We now face the grim expectation we can't avoid a recession — and that's changed the political reality

image.altText: OceanGate Titan submersible floating at the surface of the ocean

items.synopsis: Here's what an implosion means, how it happens and whether the passengers on the Titan submersible could have felt it.

title.children: 'They wouldn't have realised they were dying': What we know about the Titanic sub implosion

image.altText: Aerial view of rows of new houses in outer suburbia.

items.synopsis: Right now, evidence suggests a chronic lack of supply and increased demand for housing are supporting property prices and could lead to a further lift in the market, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Tens of thousands of 'missing' homes could push Australia's property prices even higher

image.altText: Silhouetted figure of a woman to the left, farm gate to the right. Sunset in the centre

items.synopsis: The ABC can reveal there is a court battle to keep a man who abducted and raped a German backpacker 10 years ago behind bars, with forensic psychiatrists fearing he was a high risk of reoffending.

title.children: A German backpacker responded to an ad to nanny in remote Queensland. It was a sex offender's trap

image.altText: The nose of an airliner is reconstructed from damaged pieces.

items.synopsis: The Australian government hits three of the men behind the downing of flight MH17 with sanctions and travel bans in a move likely to further inflame tensions with Russia.

title.children: Australia imposes travel bans and sanctions against three men over MH17

image.altText: Nurses and doctor pictured during medical procedure, generic image.

items.synopsis: The controversial tool has been implemented in Auckland, taking a person's ethnicity into account when placing them on non-urgent surgery waitlists.

title.children: Ethnicity criteria to rank patients for surgery in New Zealand labelled 'a courageous move'

image.altText: A silhouette of sharks under a surfer.

items.synopsis: From magnets to smelly wax, electric fields to orca calls, the shark-deterrent market is booming. Here's how the different devices stack up to research.

title.children: Personal shark deterrents are flooding the market, but research shows some may work better than others

image.altText: A man in a black collared shirt standing up holding a beer glass

items.synopsis: The 51-year-old was arrested and charged with the alleged rape of four women in Perth in the 1990s after police came forth with fresh DNA testing.

title.children: Man charged with raping four women in Perth in the 1990s after fresh DNA testing revealed

image.altText: A photo of a woman smiling at a camp site

items.synopsis: Iveta Mitchell vanished from her Parmelia home in 2010, never to be seen again — with the WA deputy coroner finding she is dead and another person is responsible.

title.children: WA coroner finds foul play in the death of Perth mother Iveta Mitchell, who vanished in 2010

image.altText: Green lawn and a straight path lead to steps to an old-fashioned building.

items.synopsis: Tamara Lorimer is found guilty of manslaughter in the Supreme Court for reversing a car over her partner in their driveway while under the influence of alcohol.

title.children: Five years' jail for Broome woman who ran over partner in 'tragedy' with 'no winners'

image.altText: Image of two old phone boxes at a road house in northern Western Australia.

items.synopsis: Christopher Andrew Anderson, who stalked women and used information he collected to harass them while committing sex acts from a payphone box, has been sentenced to four years and six months' jail.

title.children: Man who used single payphone to harass women across Australia jailed for almost five years

image.altText: eX de Medici

items.synopsis: In the face of Australia's political conservatism, punk tattoo and visual artist eX de Medici chose a perhaps unlikely weapon: watercolour.

title.children: Howard’s election made this tattooist so mad, she embraced a 'tool of destruction'

image.altText: The bow of the RMS Titanic.

items.synopsis: From the sustained pop culture boost brought on by James Cameron's 1997 blockbuster to the psychology of voyeurism, there are many reasons humanity remains fascinated with the iconic 1912 shipwreck.

title.children: Why is the Titanic's wreckage such a drawcard for explorers?

image.altText: Close-up of platypus

items.synopsis: A Wildlife Preservation Society of Queensland survey after last year's floods found Sandy Creek, which skirts the edges of western Brisbane and Ipswich, is home to a significant platypus population.

title.children: Between three motorways and in a heavily industrialised area, one of Australia's most elusive creatures can be found

image.altText: Creekbed and road overflowing with water outside a house

items.synopsis: A rainband stretching more than 3,000 kilometres will engulf Australia next week, delivering soaking rains from the Pilbara and Kimberley, across the outback to the eastern seaboard.

title.children: Week-long drenching forecast across Australia as El Niño takes a rain check

image.altText: Two women standing and not looking at each other with view of skyline, mountains and clouds in the background.

items.synopsis: Australian politics is facing a sexual harassment reckoning. Thanks to a crucial scene in a Netflix political drama, so is Taiwan. How did the show Wave Makers become a rallying cry for Taiwan's MeToo movement, and why has it taken so long for people to come forward with allegations of sexual harassment?

title.children: What does 'eating tofu' have to do with Taiwan's rising #MeToo movement?

image.altText: Rows and rows of cylinders in cages sit on tarmac. In the background are excavators, trees and water tanks

items.synopsis: This toxic waste dump in Victoria contained every thing from PFAS to asbestos — and even cash and a dog wrapped in a mattress — buried in 32 locations, some the size of AFL fields. Now $40 million later, the clean-up is almost complete.

title.children: How Australia's 'most complex' toxic waste clean-up changed the recycling industry forever

image.altText: Indiana Jones prepares to swap a gold idol for a bag of sand in a scene from Raiders Of The Lost Ark.

items.synopsis: The fifth Indiana Jones film is here, but is it the end for the whip-cracking archaeologist?

title.children: Is The Dial of Destiny really the end for Indiana Jones?

image.altText: Australian Opals basketballers Darcee Garbin and Tess Madgen pose with basketballs , in front of the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

items.synopsis: After claiming a memorable bronze medal at the 2022 Women’s World Cup, the national women’s basketball team will take to the court in Sydney on Monday with qualification for the 2024 Paris Olympics on the line.

title.children: Why the Opals are heading to the Women’s Basketball Asia Cup closer than ever

image.altText: a group of soldiers sitting inside a military helicopter

items.synopsis: Peter Rudland was badly injured in a Blackhawk helicopter crash in Afghanistan that killed four special forces soldiers in 2010. More than a decade later he's racing in his first wheelchair marathon.

title.children: Commando Peter Rudland suffered life-changing injuries in a helicopter crash. Now he's doing a marathon

image.altText: Two hand hold out a pile of black fertiliser pellets.

items.synopsis: Spreading human waste onto crops may not sound appealing, but a multi-million-dollar Icon Water scheme is hoping to turn Canberra's sewage into a valuable farming product.

title.children: Turning poo into produce: Canberra's plan to make fertiliser from human waste

image.altText: Young woman squats down on an indoor court, holding a yellow ball and smiling.

items.synopsis: After fleeing war-torn Northern Iraq, Ezidi migrants are finding their feet in regional NSW through a weekly volleyball game.

title.children: How the international language of sport is helping migrants build new lives

image.altText: A close up of a stone cross on top of a church roof with grey background.

items.synopsis: A former Catholic priest who is serving a prison sentence for sexually abusing schoolboys in Victoria, will be sentenced over more indecent assault charges in Tasmania.

title.children: 'All I wanted was to have a normal life, but he took that away from me'

image.altText: Top End dragon fruit farmer Vuong Nguyen and wife Lisa stand in the paddock with vines in the background.

items.synopsis: Buying a mango farm while on holiday has brought its fair share of challenges, but the Nguyen family haven't looked back.

title.children: From Vietnam to Sydney to Darwin: The Nguyens came for a holiday and stayed 10 years

image.altText: Greg Webb smiles at camera in half-built home

items.synopsis: After losing his home in the Black Summer bushfires, Greg Webb spent almost $300,000 on extras to disaster-proof his new house. Are such designs a blueprint for the future?

title.children: There's a growing push for more 'resilience' in Australian houses. So what does that look like?

image.altText: Firefighters investigate the scene of an explosion in a Thailand school.

items.synopsis: A fire extinguisher exploded and killed a student during a fire drill held outdoors in sweltering heat at a high school in Thailand’s capital on Friday.

title.children: Exploding fire extinguisher kills a student and injures five in Bangkok

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair and a yellow backpack takes a photo of the Parthenon in Athens, Greece, on a sunny day

items.synopsis: Younger travellers have become convenient scapegoats for destinations that refuse to take control of hyper-tourism. It's time to decide whether we want these monuments' survival, or the unthrottled stream of tourism dollars, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: With travellers swarming European destinations this summer, they're now paying the price

image.altText: A man playing the didgeridoo. A woman playing the flute. And a man playing the cello.

items.synopsis: This weekend's Classic 100 concert reminds us to celebrate the magic of instruments and the stories they tell to us, for us and about us, writes Zan Rowe.

title.children: The ABC Classic 100 reminds us that anyone and everyone can pick up an instrument

image.altText: A composite image of Salesi Piutau, Tumua Manu and Peni Matawalu on the field.

items.synopsis: Fiji, Samoa and Tonga have all announced their first squads ahead of the men's Rugby World Cup — take a deep dive into the data behind each position to see how the teams have evolved through each campaign and what's likely to come.

title.children: Explore how the Pacific Islands are looking for the Rugby World Cup

image.altText: Elaine Pandilovski smiles for a photo, dressed in a blue scarf and grey cardigan.

items.synopsis: Melbourne man Zoran Pandilovski has been labelled "evil" by members of his estranged wife's family, after the Supreme Court heard he choked his high school sweetheart, Elaine, to death and took photos of her body.

title.children: Tributes for 'beautiful, loving' Melbourne mother murdered by estranged husband

image.altText: A powerline box with a warning sign on it surrounded by bush with debris in the background.

items.synopsis: Russia has launched a High Court challenge against the federal government's decision to stop it building a new embassy next to Parliament House.

title.children: Russia launches High Court Challenge over scrapped embassy development

image.altText: Annabel Sutherland smiles while holding her bat and helmet aloft

items.synopsis: England powers to a strong score on day two of the women's Ashes, as Australia lets a crucial wicket slip after choosing not to review.

title.children: DRS strikes again as England reclaims ground on Australia after Sutherland's ton
